awd_titl_txt: TRIPODS+X:RES:Collaborative Research: Learning with Expert-In-The-Loop for Multimodal Weakly Labeled Data and an Application to Massive Scale Medical Imaging
awd_abstract_narration:
The methods developed in this project address pressing problems at the interface of machine learning and a life-sciences application. This work hopes to spur a rich variety of followup research that not only builds on the mathematical tools developed but also on the insights gained from the project's focus on interpretable and interactive machine learning. As a key application, implementation of the technology obtained from this research on medical images will enable automatic report generation. This technology could reduce the workload of radiologists significantly, and hence reduce human error and optimize resource utilization. Ultimately, reduction in human error or missing cases in radiology can greatly benefit patient well-being and care. More broadly, the work will enhance the ongoing adoption of data-driven thinking in healthcare and thereby help accelerate new discoveries. This project also impacts education, and involves intellectual and professional development of students at a variety of academic stages. 

Most applications of machine learning to medical imaging (and other human-centric tasks) focus on supervised learning, which demands a large amount of expensive labeled-data. This limitation recurs throughout applications, while real-world use of machine learning demands robustness as well as an ability to work with limited supervision. This project focuses on developing new machine learning tools for working with weak-supervision, while advancing state-of-the-art in interpretable and interactive learning. Moreover, attention to large-scale data and incorporation of domain knowledge is paid, whenever feasible. The project shall also apply the theoretical advances that it will make to a real-world medical imaging application. Theoretical advances of the proposed work will rely on tools from geometry, especially metric learning (including over infinite dimensional spaces), mathematical models motivated by optimal transport theory, as well as nonlinear representations based on neural networks as well as kernel methods.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Background

The primary focus of this project was to develop new machine learning (ML) models that can learn from weakly-supervised as well as unsupervised data. Most domains that involve learning ML models suffer from a paucity of expert labeled data, whereas a vast body of success stories of ML reported in the media are centered around supervised learning that involves a vast number of labeled data. 

Key Outcomes

This project had multiple key outcomes towards it goals:

  1. Develop basic theory that quantifies how "weak supervision" can provably help ML models to reduce the amount of "strong supervision" required. This work marks a starting point (for many) of such theory.
  2. A ML model and algorithm to learn how to encode raw data (via so-called constrastive learning) that makes more efficient use of training data by avoiding uninformative "negative" training data points. The PIs call this work "Learning with hard negatives" and it has gone on to influence numerous follow up works too.
  3. A new ML model and algorithm that performs contrastive encoding of data, but this time by seeking to learn representations of data that are not merely "easy" to learn but are more meaningful for the end task. In particular, the work strives hard to avoid learning just any representation that seems to work by avoiding so-called "shortcuts" to learn representations that are actually predictive of the ML concept being learned. There is an MIT News article about this work that provides a layman's explanation to this topic of avoiding shortcuts.
  4. Finally, the work involved the development of new theorems and mathematical results related to matrix theory, given that many optimization algorithms and methods needed in machine learning rely on tools from optimization over matrices, as well as computation of similarity between objects, some of which can often be encoded as matrices.

Most of the outcomes of this project are available as published papers at venues such as ICLR, ICML, NeurIPS, AAAI, LAA. The software code for the learning methods is available via github, and teaching material that resulted from this project has been incorporated into lectures taught by the PIs as part of curricula at their respective universities.


Last Modified: 06/18/2022
Modified by: Suvrit Sra
